etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French tradicion, or from Latin traditio(n-), from tradere ‘deliver, betray’, from trans- ‘across’ + dare ‘give’

definitions: the transmission of customs or beliefs from generation to generation, or the fact of being passed on in this way

examples.text: every shade of color is fixed by tradition and governed by religious laws

shortDefinitions: transmission of customs or beliefs from generation to generation

definitions: a long-established custom or belief that has been passed on from one generation to another
shortDefinitions: long-established custom or belief that has been passed on from one generation to another

definitions: an artistic or literary method or style established by an artist, writer, or movement, and subsequently followed by others

examples.text: visionary works in the tradition of William Blake

shortDefinitions: artistic or literary method or style established by artist

definitions: a doctrine believed to have divine authority though not in the scriptures.
shortDefinitions: doctrine believed to have divine authority though not in scriptures

definitions: (in Christianity) doctrine not explicit in the Bible but held to derive from the oral teaching of Jesus and the Apostles.
shortDefinitions: (in Christianity) doctrine not explicit in Bible but held to derive from oral teaching of Christ

definitions: (in Judaism) an ordinance of the oral law not in the Torah but held to have been given by God to Moses.
shortDefinitions: (in Judaism) ordinance of oral law not in Torah but held to have been given by God

definitions: (in Islam) a saying or act ascribed to the Prophet but not recorded in the Koran.
shortDefinitions: (in Islam) saying or act ascribed to Prophet but not recorded in Koran
